review.title: Observing Trends in Automated Multilingual Media Analysis
review.abstract: Any large organisation, be it public or private, monitors the media for information to keep abreast of developments in their field of interest, and usually also to become aware of positive or negative opinions expressed towards them. At least for the written media, computer programs have become very efficient at helping the human analysts significantly in their monitoring task by gathering media reports, analysing them, detecting trends and - in some cases - even to issue early warnings or to make predictions of likely future developments. We present here trend recognition-related functionality of the Europe Media Monitor (EMM) system, which was developed by the European Commission's Joint Research Centre (JRC) for public administrations in the European Union (EU) and beyond. EMM performs large-scale media analysis in up to seventy languages and recognises various types of trends, some of them combining information from news articles written in different languages and from social media posts. EMM also lets users explore the huge amount of multilingual media data through interactive maps and graphs, allowing them to examine the data from various view points and according to multiple criteria. A lot of EMM's functionality is accessibly freely over the internet or via apps for hand-held devices.

sections.heading: 2 Europe Media Monitor (EMM) – A brief Overview
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 2.1 Overview
sections.text: Europe Media Monitor (EMM) represents an entire family of media collection and analysis applications, including NewsBrief, NewsExplorer, the Medical Information System MedISys, NewsDesk and more (Steinberger et al. 2009a). EMM was developed entirely within the JRC. While the main users are the EU institutions and national authorities of the 28 EU member states, EMM has also been made available to international organisations (e.g. various sub-organisations of the United Nations, the African Union and the Organisation of American States) and the national authorities of selected partner countries of the EU. The first version of NewsBrief came online in 2002, while NewsExplorer came in 2004, but both systems processed smaller amounts of news and had less functionality. EMM currently collects an average of around 220,000 online news articles per day in seventy languages from around 5,000 different web sources (as of May 2015).

sections.heading: 2.3 Multilinguality in EMM
sections.text: Reporting on news in 70 different languages is also based on the understanding that reporting on news in different countries and languages complements each other, both in terms of content and in terms of opinions expressed in the media. By gathering and analysing different languages, EMM reduces any national or regional bias and increases coverage of facts and opinions. Many EMM users have special interests such as monitoring events that may have a negative impact on public health (e.g. disease outbreaks, wars and meetings of world leaders are usually also reported in English, but there is ample evidence that only a minority of the minor events are reported in the press outside the country in which the event takes place. Many EMM users have special interests such as monitoring events that may have a negative impact on public health (e.g. disease outbreaks, reports of food poisoning, lack of access to medicines; Linge et al. 2011) or on the stability or well-being of a country (e.g. conflicts between ethnic groups, accidents, crimes abroad, etc.), most of which we do not find news first in the media, etc.

sections.heading: 3 Trend observation and distribution statistics in EMM
sections.text: In this section, we would like to give some concrete examples of trend monitoring, as well as bird views of large amounts of media data, which give insight into the relative distribution of news content.The selection of examples shown here is based on a desire to represent different visualization principles or types, but it is also driven by the interests of EMM users, of course. Since EMM monitors large amounts of media reports from all over the world in near real time (timestamps) and tracks the information (e.g. news provenance, news source, publishing language, URL, media type, publication time, etc.), and additionally extracts categories and features (e.g. subject domain; number of related articles; names of persons, organizations, and locations; mood; combinations of features; averages, etc.), it is in principle possible to create and visualize statistics on any combination of features or features. This can be done for a specific time (most EMM users are interested in the current situation, i.e., for any situation).

sections.heading: 3.1 Bar graphs and pie charts
sections.text: The simplest and probably clearest way to present static data is through bar charts and pie charts: Figure 5 shows three different bar charts to visualize different aspects of the same selection of news documents (news provenance, countries mentioned in the articles, and topic areas / units), which give the reader an overview of the entire document collection and thus help him evaluate and categorize the content before reading it in detail. Figure 7 shows the language distribution of a multilingual group of European news articles that talk about science and technology and compare it with the language distribution in all articles from the same period.

sections.heading: 3.2 Maps visualising geographical distributions
sections.text: Map views are quite popular and intuitive. Figure 5 shows an aggregated map view (number of items per continent / country / region, depending on the zoom level), while Figure 6 shows all message clusters (or those in a selection of languages) that EMM currently sees. Since much map data is available as pre-built levels (terrain, borders, roads, airports, etc.), map visualization can be quite powerful. Figure 8 shows the result of EMM's event detection software, represented by Google Earth.4 All map data in EMM is linked to websites that contain the original news articles along with the extracted meta information, so that users can view live event maps.4, go to http: / / emm.newsbrief.eu / NewsBrief / eventedition / en / latest _ en.html and select the KML output format. It is also possible to display events in all eight languages on the same map, by selecting the source of the 2006 Paris / html / first edition of the event map, for example.
